importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on this date and reports on the latest developments regarding Curtis Sliwa’s mayoral campaign, including pressure from John Catsimatidis and responses from Sliwa and Zohran Mamdani.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The key events involving Sliwa’s potential exit, Catsimatidis’s public call, Trump’s comments, and the debate dynamics occurred in this timeframe.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, is facing pressure to withdraw from the race, notably from his boss John Catsimatidis.
John Catsimatidis, a supermarket magnate and owner of WABC radio, publicly urged Sliwa to drop out, citing a need for Sliwa to prioritize New York City’s interests over his personal ambitions.
Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is actively rallying Republicans to support him and oppose Sliwa, arguing he is a less viable alternative to Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist.
Sliwa has rejected the pressure, asserting that he represents blue-collar working-class voters and criticizing Cuomo for relying on billionaire donors to influence the election.
President Donald Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime,' mocking his cat-related public image and interests, signaling broader Republican skepticism.
Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic nominee, has dismissed claims of coordination with Sliwa, emphasizing that both candidates are focused on appealing directly to New Yorkers.
Sliwa has been a perennial mayoral candidate since 2021, with no prior political office, and currently polls third behind Mamdani and Cuomo.
The political dynamics reflect a broader tension between grassroots, working-class candidates and billionaire-backed, establishment figures in New York’s mayoral race.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor with no prior political office, is under pressure to drop out of the race after his boss, John Catsimatidis, publicly urged him to withdraw, citing a need to prioritize New York’s interests. The pressure comes as Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, seeks to consolidate Republican support to oppose Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist, by dismissing Sliwa as a weak alternative. Sliwa has responded by rejecting this narrative, emphasizing that he represents blue-collar, working-class voters and criticizing Cuomo and billionaire donors for shaping the election. The article highlights growing tension between grassroots, community-based candidates and establishment figures, with both Sliwa and Mamdani asserting that voters, not donors, should determine the city’s future. President Donald Trump has also dismissed Sliwa, mocking his cat-related image and political style, further underscoring the skepticism surrounding his candidacy.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
